comments.commentBody: There is something very unsettling when the POTUS is telling Americans to "write/email" their congressmen! Doesn't he understand that he was elected to LEAD  not to organize a letter writing  committee! ?    ( Can someone get him a copy of his office's job description??)

Oh my - you liberal Americans are all so reasonable and whilst you remain so reasonable your TP oppomnents who don't know the meaning of the word will trsmple all over you. Your President reflects your attitudes perfectly. Would you support him if he really used his quite immense powers? He has used the veto only twice: just look how feeble that looks compared with FDR.

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_United_States_presidential_vetoes#S...

Of course FDR understood the ruling class, he was a member of it. He knew they could not be governed by reason they had to be forced to obey.
But if Obama tried such tactics it's likely that even you would turn on him.

From his record of the last year Obama appears to be Republican. If one didn't know Obama was a Democrat and simply looked at what he has done and what he has allowed to continue from the corrupt Cheney/Bush reign, one would swear Obama is Republican.

Hard to understand why the GOP doesn't just keep him in office and be happy about it. The guy is so obviously on their side.

If the knuckle-head Limbaugh and the other corporate mouth-piece, what's his name, on TV just started saying how great Obama is for the Republican Party, the whole thing would make more sense. The whole shebang is so blatantly off-kilter that none of it reads true. From the actual Presidency to the loud-mouth "critics" it's all just smoke and mirrors, smoke and mirrors; but protecting whom? What cabal is behind all this warm and fussy fantasy leadership we are being force fed?

I beleive that the Democrats should concentrate on winning large majorities in both houses of congress and just write in a Presidential candidate.Obama is a lost cause.If a republican is elected as President,he wont be able to advance their agenda anyway.Barring that they should just tell Obama that he must step down.I for one will vote Republican before I will vote for him.People will write on here all of the misguided actions he ahs committed and then say,"but I will vote for him anyway"How dumb and irresponsible is that?

The President needs to go "off prompter". I've never seen this guy, NOT ONCE, fielding questions off the cuff. Bill Clinton was the master, as was Reagan. Watching O speak now after three years is like watching the crowd at a tennis match. ( side to side head movements). He even took the prompter to India, where they laughed at it. As well as to talk to school children. Jus sayin

Obama has gotten so caught up in appeasing Republicans, he's forgotten why he was elected - to serve the people.

He had gobs of political capital when he was inaugurated but he's frittered it away. Now, one likes him. Not the Republicans, who he tried to win over nor the independents who don't know what he stands for nor the Democrats, who feel betrayed.

Obama wasted a golden opportunity. But rather than learning from his mistake, he just keeps doing the same thing all over again.

"The president still believes he can use his enchanting powers to convert the other side . . . "

I voted for him. But (apparently) believing that he has enchanting powers has always been, in my opinion, Obama's problem, both during the 2008 campaign, right up through today. He's a guy who seems to rely on charm rather than putting in the hard work of leading.

I voted for Obama and had high hopes. But because he has been so weak, so willing to concede ground without getting anything in return, so unwilling to fight for what he professes to stand for....I now think it might be better if a Republican wins the presidency in 2012. Then we would get another shot at putting someone with moxie in the WH in 2016. (Assuming the country survives 4 years of Rick Perry).

Yawn.  More buyer's remorse from another NY Times columinist who championed President Obama, buying everything he had said and then some.  Even I, who has just a B.A. in history and English, knew better.  I took the time to assess the total package, and was far less then impressed.  I examined his Senate record, both in Illinois and in the U.S. Senate.  I also investigated who was financially supporting the man outside of grass roots suckers.  That was what decided me in voting against him.

What do we expect when our institutions of "higher learning" turn out technocrats and our public schools turn out marginally literate texters?

We need to face the fact that our society is dysfunctional. The system is wrong. What began as a violent taking and enslavement continues due to our choice for denial over truth. That we have devolved into a pile of narcissistic hubris should come as no surprise. Cleverness will not get us out of this, only the truth - and that starts with each one of us.

Obama is but a bit player on a large stage and the voters play right along with him. We are all dysfunctional.

My solution: I won't vote. I simply will not encourage them. I organize community where I am, but I will not participate in a political system that works like a Ponzi scheme.

My cynical side tells me that what the President proposes will not be bold enough to make a difference nor explained in terms that the general public will understand to be in their best interest ( though it probably will be). It will lean towards being balanced with things the Republicans have supported in the past and would sound rational and reasonable to a rational and reasonable Congress. The outcome will be more political deadlock to match the anticipated reception of the committee of 12 suggestions. For a 2008 Obama backer, this outcome will be a sad one for our country.

The President must think out of the box and come up with proposed solutions that literally galvanize the voters to demand that his new programs be implemented...marches (peaceful and disciplined of course) on D.C. might help. Shame the opposition into agreement. It just may get him re-elected as a side benefit! Perhaps this scenario is just a nice fantasy for those who still have faith in his capability.

President Obama should do the truly courageous thing and announce that he is not running for a second term. He is unable to lead as this country needs him to do. I believed what he said three years ago. I gave him more money than I have ever given to a political candidate.
If he were to announce that he was not running, he would be able to, hopefully, put some things that he wants to do in action without having to worry about the "repercussions".
More importantly, by doing so, he might give encouragement to SOMEONE to run for the office who might be able to lead us out of this mess that this country has become.
There ARE some good Republican candidates out there. But maybe they think it is not worth running in 2012. As much as it may sound racist, if Obama runs, there will be AGAIN a huge turnout of minorities, as there was in 2008 (AS THERE WASN'T IN 2010!!) and Obama will be hard to beat. These GOOD Republicans also might not feel they want to get caught up in the "issues" that the current Republican candidates proffer...all the anti-Obama-isms. If the current Republican candidates didn't have Obama to run against, they wouldn't know what to campaign FOR.
If Obama was to decide NOT to run, it might also "free-up" some Democratic candidate who currently doesn't want to pull a "Ted Kennedy" and help Sarah Palin win.
I admire the man, but he is not who we need in this office.

I love it when folks say "he was dealt a bad hand"' etc. They use this to justify his poor performance. Was it a worse hand then FDR, or Lincoln, or Nixon with Viet Nam, or Truman. Not even Lincoln blamed his troubles on the other guys. Lincolns foes wanted him dead. How about LBJ? Did Obama have a worse hand? This guy is simply not up to the task and he won't learn or listen. He thinks he is smarter than all of you.

P.S. I voted for him as well as McGovern, Carter, and Clinton.

Excellent column. I enjoy your humor, but perhaps your columns should take a serious tone more often. We need strong voices like yours to urge Obama to free himself from his "altruistically moral" mindset. The Frost poem and comments of LuAnn Lavine say it all. Hopefully, Obama is reading the Times as well as Frost poems and Brave New World while he's on vacation.

Real change, however, will require more than backbone. Fresh ideas are needed, ideas that bypass Washington. Otherwise our most pressing problems - creating jobs and keeping people in their homes - will never be resolved. It pains me to hear Obama limit his jobs initiative to tired old ideas that require action by Congress. It’s time for him to inspire and enlist the help of the American people who have always come through in times of crisis.

Joe Nocera - another strong voice - recently asked in these pages what businesses are waiting for before acting in their own self interest and investing the trillions dollars of cash they are holding in rebuilding our economy, instead of just seeking short term gains from volatile global financial markets. Obama must articulate innovative ideas that respond to Joe’s question, among others. The same old ideas just won’t work.

In short, businesses and citizens must be inspired to move our country ahead. It is clear Washington can’t get the job done. So, Obama not only needs to “take his own side in the quarrel,” but he also must propose and facilitate bold new, and effective, ideas that can be implemented without waiting for our feckless politicians who are too busy bickering - or vacationing - to do their jobs.

You say it so well, but does the Great Compromiser and Surrenerer read? It might disturb his vacation.

What fools both he and his advisors are. Yes , he could gover as well from the Island of the Wealthy as from DC, but remaining in DC would send a visual image of concern. And Michelle (no Eleanor) can stay in MA to be in touch by Skype.)

A one term president? Maybe, the opponents can't be that much worse!

---when Blair came on the scene we scratched our heads and wondered---gave him the benefit of the doubt until 2003---he said he had moral convictions---we did not know that he was psychologically flawed---Obama came and the world was hopeful---he seemed like sanity personified---then we heard his pre-election speech to AIPAC and we wondered---and then he appointed Clinton as Foreign Secretary and we knew there was something wrong---would I vote for him again?---I would---just look at the other contenders---he will re-form himself, his country and the world and like prince Hal
My reformation, glit`ring o`er my fault,
Shall show more goodly, and attract more eyes
Than that which hath no foil to set it off.

Hope!

I'm disappointed, you're disappointed, we're all disappointed in him. But what's the use of harping on our disappointment? He is what he is, not what we thought he was. The wish, as always, was father to the thought.

We should have known better, there was plenty of evidence that he was the conventional, middle of the road politician we now know him to be, in no ssense revolutinary or even innovative. And if we didn't know much about him, we certainly knew something about his advisors, e.g., Rahm Emanuel, David Axelrod, et al, nobody who could be remotely suspected of liberalism.

But did we, after all, have a choice? Yes, our dear old one-and-a-half party system offered the usual, greater vs. lesser evil choice. So we - we liberals - got used to holding our noses and voting Democrat. but we thought this election, 2008, would be different. The more fools we.

There's no use complaining, Maureen, he's not going to change. He'll keep on giving us his silly sermons about "bipartisanship" while his enemies - and ours - laugh at him. And we know that if he doesn't change, he'll probably lose in 2012. And then some know-nothing Tea Party creep will ge president.

So what should we do? it's retty clear Gore won't challenge him for the nomination, so how about you? Or Steve Colbert? or Dowd & Colbert? (we'll let you two fight it out for top billing).

Maureen, you have the mood of the people right. You are fumbling with Obama, bouncing between what you think down deep (not good) and what you would like to believe. By October you should have it together...
The president inhabits the"Obama Oasis," populated with his neighbors: "Leaderless," "Whiner," and "Bad Luck," and "No Luck At All."

Having had the opportunity to see many productions, there is nothing that compares to "War Horse."  Wondering if there will ever be anything equal to or near equal to it in New York again.  Probably not.  Give yourself a lifetime opportunity - see it.

the problem is that big businesses are not the people with the practical advise, it is the small and medium sized businesses. the whole system of the fed and the financial markets is engineered to keep the stock markets and real estate artificially inflated. the real models to study are germany, taiwan and to a lesser extent singapore, and the plan for the US is quite simple:

SIMPLIFY THE TAX CODE. remove all government supports for home ownership like the mortgage tax write-off. an affordable flat tax irregardless of income is extremely democratic and the studies show it will bring in a lot of money. it will also free up the lost productivity companies and individuals use filing and avoiding taxes. it should be no more than 10% for federal taxes.

REGULATE THE BANKING INDUSTRY: homes should never be allowed to be speculative investments, not for individuals, nor for institutions. homes should be an affordable right for ALL citizens. enact same rules and that encourage fair prices and low balance mortgages. start by simply making a rule that stipulates you can not use the work "purchase", "own", or "sale" for cases when a mortgage is used. for example: be clear: "HOME FOR SALE OR MORTGAGE LEASE TO OWN FROM BANK".

NATIONALIZE HEALTH INSURANCE: no other industrialized nations wastes as much money as the US on health care. it is a huge expense that contributes to unemployment. a company with 10 employees in new york or california now spends the same amount of money on health insurance premiums as the cost of keeping 1 additional employee – do the math! that solves 10% unemployment right there!

NO CORPORATE or LOW CORPORATE TAXES and equalize capital gains to one rate of 10%.

i can go into more detail but no space. ten again, the govt has never responded to my letters offering my advise as an entrepreneur and small businessman....

When are w going to learn that major corporate and financial interests don't really care about America, our families and communities? Their focus has been and likely will remain maximization of short term profits for the benefit of a narrow few, at ALL costs. When the NT Times and virtually all journalists talk about Business they virtually always mean BIG business, the US Chamber of Commerce and it's ilk.
it's time we understand and highlight that the vast majority of business in America are small too mid-size, under 500 employees - 99 percent. over 55 percent of us work in a small business. those of us in and running our smaller companies care deeply about our communities and country. We're highly committed to our local job creation and yet the press is silent on this critical sector of our economy and national culture and life. We clearly understand spreadsheets and would love to be invited to the White House, testify in Congress and committees about out thoughts concerning our vision and ideas for improving the economy and job creation. Who do you think is creating new jobs?
It's time that the media, policy makers and the public begin listening to those of us who actually create new enterprises ts

Your editorial begins with a common mistake, the assumption that the skills needed to rise to the top of the business world are the same as those needed to run a business. Sadly this is not true. Those who rise to the top have excellent political skills but rely on the business skills of those they left behind on the corporate ladder to make them look good. The result is what we saw in the ginned up debt ceiling crisis where business leaders were playing politics just as vigorously as the DC denizens. It is also why the corporate world is composed of the biggest welfare queens the world has ever seen while to many Americans worry about being able to feed their families.

One doesn't get to read an editorial that is this steeped in cluelessness and is as disconnected as is this one very often. 'Wesley Mouch', you've exceeded your own limitations!

Firstly, there is no business who should willingly come riding to the aid of Leftists. Your policies, collectively, are anathema to this nation's success; your actions (including the over-regulating of industry, embedding your Party with corrupt Unions, your meme-speak that demonizes Corporations as 'not even people' and demonizes the 'rich' as 'not paying their fair share') are plain-spoken enough: Leftists who now control the once-proud Democratic party desire only to buy votes and support from community-organized Moochers using Other People's Money. There's no consideration given to the needs of businesses or corporations until you 'want' more from them, for to wrench away more taxes used to expedite your causes.

Secondly, the policies you are begging monies for are doomed anyway. The various social welfare programs won't last: Social Security is, as all realize, doomed to fail. Medicare and Medicaid, and this newly-created monstrously damaging program ObamaCare, will drain this Republic's treasury dry (wait..they already have).

Mr. Koch responds to Mr. Buffet, and indirectly, to you:

“Much of what the government spends money on does more harm than good; this is particularly true over the past several years with the massive uncontrolled increase in government spending. I believe my business and non-profit investments are much more beneficial to societal well-being than sending more money to Washington. — Charles G. Koch, Chairman and CEO, Koch Industries, Inc.

So, that for your pipe. Enjoy your smoke!

We have a situation where the real problem is far deeper than raising taxes. It has to do with how men and women are defined as "leaders" or exemplary business people worthy of high salaries. There is a tight, impenetrable group think that has developed over the years that has a mind of its own and the operatives have become simply incapable of taking a deep breath, standing back, and asking if everything they think they stand for does not, in fact, have a foundation of sand. This group think feels dangerous to me, where anyone who comes close to making a credible case that the emperor has no clothes will suffer the equivalent of, to varying degrees, being taken out in the dark of night and shot.

I think in some degree this group think mindset is related to unexamined compromises that had to be made long ago, at the beginning of boomers' careers, when they found they had to "get with the program" or they would not be allowed to be problem-solving, contributing members of society that could earn a credible standard of living for themselves and their families. The only way those compromises can be made is if they are buried, without a real examination of what has taken place. The result is truncated problem solving, where one can feel they are doing the right thing because it benefits their company or their family or some small part of their world but in fact often contributes to the worsening of the global condition. They give in to broad generalizations about "free market economy" without really thinking through how what they are participating in is really affecting the "free market." Warren Buffet is a breath of fresh air but I lack the information to know if he isn't also part of the problem, ultimately. One could only hope the market crash of a few years ago would facilitate a deeper examination of this but it hasn't. In its irrationality in terms of obstructing true problem solving it has become the last, impenetrable line of defense of the corporate mindset.
